awd_titl_txt: Redox, Electronic, and Rectifying Response of Five- and Six-coordinate Metallosurfactants in Solution, as Films, and on Electrodes
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project funded by the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program of the Division of Chemistry, Professor Cláudio N. Verani and his research group at Wayne State University in Detroit are studying metal-based molecules able to act as diodes for electric current rectification. Rectification, or directional current flow from an electrode A to an electrode B (but not from B back to A) is fundamental to the conversion of alternating into direct current, and is absolutely necessary for electronic data computation. This interdisciplinary proposal seeks to enhance our fundamental understanding on the use of metallosurfactants for molecular diodes.  Broader impacts include scientific outreach to fourth and fifth graders and effort to promote Latino-student inclusion in STEM research.

Verani and collaborators are studying the redox, electronic, and rectifying behavior of metallosurfactants, both in solution and as Langmuir-Blodgett monolayer films deposited onto gold electrodes. Therefore, this interdisciplinary program focuses on the use of amphiphilic coordination complexes towards current-rectifying assemblies as measured by the asymmetry of current/potential (I/V) curves aiming to understand (i) the predominant rectification mechanisms in metallosurfactants; (ii) the possibility of electron-transfer mediation in metal-based singly occupied molecular orbitals (SOMOs); (iii) the viability of electron transfer mediation by metals between ligand-centered lowest unoccupied & highest occupied molecular orbitals (LUMOS & HOMOs); (iv) the role of metallosurfactant orientation in the mechanism of rectification; (v) the influence of the metallosurfactant geometry in observed symmetric conduction, unimolecular or asymmetric rectification, or insulation. This research is multi-faceted, incluidng efforts to make strides in synthetic methodologies, and in electrochemical, spectroscopic, computational, isothermal compression, and microscopy methods.

por.por_cntn:
In this project funded by the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry program of the Division of Chemistry, Prof Claudio Verani and his research group at Wayne State University in Detroit, Michigan, studied the properties and behavior of metallosurfactants (Figure 1). These molecules have a series of unique properties: (i) they contain metals, (ii) they behave like surfactants (soaps), (iii) they can form organized films, and (iv) they are able to direct electric current flow from an electrode A to an electrode B while blocking current from coming back from B to A. This study is fundamental in nature but teaches us important information relevant to the conversion of alternating into direct current, and the understanding of electronic data computation.  It is the 21st century equivalent of what Thomas Edison did in the 1880s, when he tested thousands of new materials before he concluded that carbonized bamboo could be used as filaments in the then nascent technology of incandescent light bulbs; an important first step towards tungsten filament and mercury-vapor fluorescent lamps.

 Verani et al. synthesized these new molecules and studied their redox, electronic, and interfacial organization both in solution and as Langmuir-Blodgett films. These thin films have the thickness of a single molecule and were deposited onto several substrates like glass, mica or gold. This interdisciplinary research brought cutting edge data and understanding on (i) the mechanisms preferred by metallosurfactants to transfer and transport electrons; (ii) the identity of the orbitals, or regions of probability of finding electros in a molecule, in which transfer/transport takes place; in this case these orbitals are the so called singly occupied molecular orbitals (SOMOs); (iii) how the orientation of the metallosurfactants, when organized as a thin film, facilitates or hampers this electron transfer/transport, (v) what is the influence of the metallosurfactant?s geometry in conducting electrons, and their relationship to the selected mechanism.

 The successful study of these topics required a certain unique background in synthetic, electrochemical, spectroscopic, computational, isothermal compression, and microscopy methodology that is unique to the Verani group, whereas engaged outreach included the dissemination of this knowledge in the form of publications, symposia organization, journal editing, Latino inclusion, and scientific awakening of undergraduate student. The P.I. presented results of this research during the 45th IUPAC World Chemistry Congress in Busan, Korea (2015) and in the meeting ISACS: Challenges in Inorganic Chemistry organized by the Royal Society of Chemistry in Manchester, UK (2016), Beijing Computational Science Research Center Building (2017), an in both the Inorganic Chemistry and the Donor-Acceptor Chemistry Gordon Research Conferences (2018). He also gave talks at the universities of Arizona, Houston, Texas at Austin, Memphis, North Carolina State, Tulane, and Louisiana State, as well as at the Fluminense Federal University in Brazil, and UNIST in Korea. Students working on this project presented 4 talks and 20 posters in several meetings. From five new Ph.D. graduates in the group from this same period, two students were directly associated with this grant.

A total of 11 papers were published acknowledging this grant; as such, during this period we confirmed along with the Metzger group the rectifying behavior of our flagship iron(III) surfactant using methodology alternative to that in our labs (J. Phys.Chem. C., 2016, 120, 10578), we developed the theoretical arguments of electronic modulation of the energy needed between the orbital of the metallosurfactant and that of the surface (Chem. Eur. J. 2016, 22, 10786), we studied along with the Brand group in great detail and for the first time the orientation changes of metallosurfactant films during the electrochemical process (Dalton Trans. 2018,47, 14218), we developed new molecular architectures for rectification, including asymmetric species  (Dalton Trans. 2018, 47, 6344) and species containing two metal centers (Dalton Trans. 2018, 47, 14352). These accomplishments were placed in perspective to the field of molecular electronics in an invited review (Dalton Trans. 2018, 47, 14153). Based on our experimental model, we also attempted to apply those principles to (i) preclude electron transfer in specific metal surfaces (Chem. Commun. 2016 52, 11155), and (ii) foster electron-transfer in catalytic metallosurfactants (Chem. Commun. 2016, 52, 8440 and Inorg. Chem. 2018, 57, 9748). Additionally, we acknowledged the use of existing infrastructure in another paper (J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2016, 138, 4006).

Overall, this was a very productive research, and the P.I. and his group are very thankful to the National science Foundation for this opportunity
